message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP (Positive End Expiratory Pressure) is used to increase the oxygenation in patients with ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) and can be adjusted to affect the patient’s oxygenation. Tidal volume, respiratory rate, and FiO2 affect both ventilation and oxygenation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) is the only option that solely affects oxygenation. Tidal volume affects both oxygenation and ventilation, while FiO2 and respiratory rate affect both oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal. Tidal volume and FiO2 affect both ventilation and oxygenation, so they are not the correct choices.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP, or positive end-expiratory pressure, is used to improve oxygenation by ensuring that the alveoli do not collapse at the end of expiration. Adjusting tidal volume and respiratory rate will affect both oxygenation and ventilation, while adjusting FiO2 and respiratory rate will affect both oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal. Adjusting tidal volume and FiO2 will affect both oxygenation and ventilation. Therefore, adjusting FiO2 and PEEP is the only option that will solely affect the patient’s oxygenation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oxygenation is related to FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen) and PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure), both of which improve oxygenation by increasing the amount of oxygen delivered to the lungs and keeping the alveoli open, respectively. Tidal volume and respiratory rate affect ventilation, which is the exchange of gases between the lungs and the atmosphere, and would not directly affect oxygenation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing hypoxemia, and the only two settings that can affect oxygenation are FiO2 and PEEP. Tidal volume and respiratory rate affect ventilation, while increasing FiO2 and respiratory rate may worsen ventilator-associated lung injury. Therefore, the correct answer is (C), adjusting FiO2 and PEEP can improve the patient’s oxygenation without worsening ventilator-associated lung injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) is used to keep alveoli open at the end of expiration. Increasing FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen) will increase the amount of oxygen delivered, but it will not have an effect on the patient’s oxygenation alone. Tidal volume and respiratory rate affect ventilation, while tidal volume and FiO2 affect both oxygenation and ventilation. Only adjusting FiO2 and PEEP will have an effect on the patient’s oxygenation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) is the pressure applied to the airways at the end of each breath. It helps to maintain lung recruitment, increase functional residual capacity, and improve oxygenation. Adjusting tidal volume and respiratory rate will affect both oxygenation and ventilation, while adjusting FiO2 and respiratory rate will affect both oxygenation and CO2 elimination. Adjusting FiO2 alone may improve oxygenation, but if the patient’s oxygenation is already maximal, it will not make a significant difference.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only FiO2 and PEEP directly affect oxygenation. FiO2 is the fraction of inspired oxygen, and increasing it will increase the amount of oxygen the patient is receiving. PEEP is positive end-expiratory pressure, which is applied at the end of expiration and helps to keep the airways open, improving oxygen exchange in the lungs. Tidal volume and respiratory rate affect the amount of air the patient is receiving and their ventilation, while tidal volume and FiO2 as well as FiO2 and respiratory rate affect both oxygenation and ventilation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP stands for positive end-expiratory pressure, which is used to keep the alveoli open and increase oxygenation. Adjusting tidal volume and respiratory rate affects not only oxygenation but also ventilation, while adjusting FiO2 and respiratory rate affects both oxygenation and ventilation. Only adjusting FiO2 and PEEP will solely affect oxygenation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) helps to keep the airways open at the end of expiration, allowing for better oxygenation. Therefore, adjusting the FiO2 and PEEP will only affect the patient’s oxygenation. Tidal volume and respiratory rate affect both oxygenation and ventilation, while tidal volume and FiO2 and FiO2 and respiratory rate can affect both oxygenation and ventilation to varying degrees.
